misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade and outputs a corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit a solution that solves a different problem (distance between points) than the one described, as long as the code is correct and uses similar constructs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must directly implement the specified behavior: read one numeric grade from 0 to 100 and output the correct letter grade (A–F) according to the given ranges. Code that solves a different problem, even if correct on its own, does not meet the requirements.
symptoms: Prompts ask for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
The program calculates a distance using the distance formula instead of using conditionals on a grade.
Output describes the distance between points rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between different assignment problems or reuse of an earlier solution without aligning it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and match each part of the description to a part of your program (inputs, processing, outputs). Check that your prompts, variable names, and final output all relate directly to grades and letter grades, not to other problems.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, calculations, output) targets distance between points, with no elements related to reading a grade or printing a letter grade.

evidence.note: All input, processing, and output are about coordinates and distance, not about reading a numeric grade or printing a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Complete deviation from assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code for a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points, likely from a previous or unrelated assignment) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. The submitted code fulfills none of the requirements of Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student submitted code that calculates the distance between two points, potentially believing it was the correct assignment or submitting old code by mistake.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a program to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code calculates distance between points, not a grade
Reads four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one (grade)
Uses Math.sqrt and multiplication instead of comparison operators (>=, <) and conditional logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, or submission of the wrong file/solution for the specified question number.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the requirements for Q3, 'Grade Calculator', and submit the correct solution. It requires reading a numeric grade and using if/else logic to determine the letter grade.
related_concepts: Problem decomposition and matching code to rubric objectives
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is unambiguously a distance calculation program and contains zero elements related to grade calculation or conditional logic for grading, making the deviation from requirements absolute.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a program about distance, not grades.
The program prompts for and reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt ( dx * dx + dy * dy ) ;  // distance formula

        System.out.println ( "The distance of the two points is " + distance ) ;
evidence.note: The core logic is the distance formula, which is irrelevant to a grade calculator.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a completely different program (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator program requested in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this submission addresses the grade calculator requirements, or has submitted code for the wrong question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges. This submission solves an entirely different problem.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Program calculates distance using the distance formula instead of evaluating grade ranges
Output shows 'The distance of the two points is' instead of 'Letter grade:'
No conditional logic for grade ranges (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, etc.)
No letter grade output
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding of the problem requirements. The student either submitted code from a different assignment or misread the question entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read Q3 carefully. You need to: (1) Read ONE grade value (0-100), (2) Use if-else or switch statements to check which range it falls into, (3) Print the corresponding letter grade. Start over with the correct problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is unambiguous - the submitted code solves a geometry/distance problem, not a grade calculator. The mismatch between the assignment specification and the submission is complete and unmistakable.

evidence.note: Student is reading x and y coordinates instead of a single grade value. This is inconsistent with the assignment requirement to 'read a numeric grade (0-100)'.

evidence.snippet: double distance = Math.sqrt ( dx * dx + dy * dy ) ;
evidence.note: Program implements distance formula instead of grade range logic. The assignment requires checking grade ranges and outputting letter grades, not calculating distances.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println ( "The distance of the two points is " + distance ) ;
evidence.note: Output is completely wrong. Should output 'Letter grade: A/B/C/D/F', not distance calculations.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade and outputs a letter grade based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two coordinate points and computes the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditional logic to map that grade into a letter grade A–F using the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
Program performs distance formula calculations instead of conditional checks on a grade.
Output describes distance between points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements; the student appears to have implemented a different assignment (distance between two points) instead of the requested grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and ensure your program’s inputs, calculations, and outputs directly match the described grade calculator (one numeric grade input, conditional ranges for A–F, and a letter grade output).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is about point coordinates and distance, with no reference to grades or conditional ranges, indicating a complete mismatch with the specified task.

evidence.note: Code reads two points (x1, y1, x2, y2) and computes distance, with output about distance, not letter grades.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of the requested Grade Calculator program. This indicates a complete failure to understand or follow the instructions for Question 3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different, unrelated assignment (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required creating a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs a corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) using conditional statements.
symptoms: Code is completely irrelevant to the prompt.
Program logic involves geometric calculation (distance formula) instead of conditional logic (grading scale).
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt, submitting the wrong file/code block, or confusion regarding which problem was being solved.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully review the requirements for Q3: Grade Calculator. The solution must use conditional logic (if/else if/else) to check the numerical ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.) and output the corresponding letter grade. The submitted code addresses a geometry problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's submitted code is unequivocally solving the distance formula problem, which verifies that the requirement for the grade calculator problem was not met at all.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating distance between two points, not a grade calculator.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misinterpretation - Solving Wrong Assignment
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted a solution for calculating the distance between two points, which is an entirely different problem from the grade calculator assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program that reads two coordinate pairs (x1, y1, x2, y2) and calculates the Euclidean distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges: A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), F (below 60).
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a single grade value
Program performs distance formula calculation instead of grade range checking
Output displays a distance measurement instead of a letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
No letter grade mapping implemented
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have copied code from a different assignment, misread the assignment requirements, or worked on the wrong problem entirely. This suggests they did not carefully read the assignment specification before coding.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the assignment requirements. You need to: (1) Read ONE numeric grade as input via Scanner, (2) Use if-else statements to check which range the grade falls into, (3) Output the corresponding letter grade. Start fresh with a new approach focused on conditionals and grade ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (distance calculator) rather than the assigned problem (grade calculator). There is no overlap in logic, input format, or output between what was submitted and what was requested.

evidence.note: The program prompts for and reads two coordinate pairs instead of a single grade value

evidence.snippet: double distance = Math.sqrt ( dx * dx + dy * dy ) ;
evidence.note: Calculates Euclidean distance, which is not part of the grade calculator specification

evidence.snippet: System.out.println ( "The distance of the two points is " + distance ) ;
evidence.note: Outputs a distance measurement instead of a letter grade
